   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, COPD, admitted to OSH with pneumonia,
   complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF,
   transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure- Likely multifactorial, with contributions from
   apparent RLL PNA, pulmonary edema 2/2 systolic CHF requiring
   intermittent diuresis, RLL pleural effusion s/p 800cc thoracentesis
   (culture data not available), and an episode of pulmonary hemorhhage
   felt [**12-31**] anticoagulation.  Overnight she did not tolerate PS trial due
   to discomfort, but oxygenation has been adequate.  Bloody secretions
   suctioned overnight suggest that pulmonary bleed may be intermittently
   continuing.  Sputum culture growing yeast only.
   - hold off on further diuresis given concern for critical AS.
   - repeat bronch this am
   - review CT imaging tonight, consider CT CHEST following bronch
   - obtain TTE, consider TEE to evaluate mitral valve
   - continue vancomcyin/zosyn for HCAP.
   - f/u OSH blood, sputum, and thoracentesis cultures (call in AM, per
   LDH, fluid was transudative, but protein unknown, empyema unlikelygiven
   pH 7.5).
   - wean peep, repeat ABG tonight, consider trial PS.
   - continue prednisone, start tapering as below.
   .
   # aortic stenosis - report of critical AS on TTE at OSH.  unclear what
   her baseline functional status is, she does not have regular angina, or
   syncope
   - repeat TTE
   - consider cardiology consult in AM.
   - hold off on further diuresis, nitrates.
   .
   # ARF - no known renal dysfunction.  found to have mild left
   hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by urology with plan to follow
   clinically.  ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic
   stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine lytes suggest
   pre-renal etiology.
   - check UA/UCx.
   - check urine lytes.
   - renal ultrasound
   - follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for
   UOP<30cc/hr.
   .
   # bacteremia - source unclear, but likely pulmonary given recent
   pneumonia.
   - continue vancomycin.
   - TTE in AM, and consider TEE.
   .
   # transaminitis - h/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  abdominal usn and ct abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Lipase not elevated
   - trend LFTs
   - repeat abdominal usn in AM.
   .
   # thrombocytopenia - more likely [**12-31**] underlying liver disease, now with
   reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  ddx also includes DIC,
   HUS/TTP given mild ARF, and HITT, though time course is unclear (he
   received heparin sc tid and lovenox at OSH)
   - check smear to r/o schistocytes (ARF, anemia, thrombocytopenia).
   - check DIC labs.
   - check for HIT.
   .
   # COPD - unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**], but not on home O2.  no clear wheezing
   on exam presently, so feel COPD less likely.
   - taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - obtain OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**] in AM.
   .
   # h/o aortic valvular thrombus - chronically anticoagulated, though
   held in the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrage (though only
   received 1U PRBC for this at OSH).   no thrombus seen on his recent TTE
   at OSH.
   - hold lovenox/coumadin for now, discuss with cardiology in AM based on
   repeat TTE here.
   - cardiology consult following echo.
   .
   # sacral decub - pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - air mattress.
   - wound care consult.
   .
   # h/o hyponatremia - resolved presently
   - trend na daily.
   .
   # OA - receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  a rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - continue morphine 0.5mg iv q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # anxiety - per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # elevated FSBS - no known history of DM,  but on steroids, with
   elevated FSBS.
   - cover with HISS.
   .
   # h/o SVT
 monitor on tele
   .
   # HTN - hold lisinopril given ARF, avoid nitro gtt given AS.
   .
   # hyperlipidemia
hold home statin given transaminitis.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.
   - nutrition consult in AM re tube feeds.
   - consider replacing NGT with OGT if not getting extubated soon.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots, PPI.
   .
   # Access: PIV, L IJ TLC, A-LINE.
   .
   # Code: FULL CODE
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son [**Name (NI) **] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9284**], [**Hospital3 **]
   floor [**Telephone/Fax (1) 9285**].
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO, nutrition c./s

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pneumonia, acute respiratory failure (ARF), and bacteremia. She was admitted to the ICU due to difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation and a possible valvuloplasty. The patient has been experiencing several medical complications, including respiratory failure, pulmonary edema, right lower lobe (RLL) pleural effusion, pulmonary hemorrhage, bacteremia, renal failure, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, and COPD exacerbation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is likely experiencing respiratory failure, which is multifactorial and may be caused by pneumonia, pulmonary edema, RLL pleural effusion, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
2. Pulmonary Edema: The patient has evidence of pulmonary edema, which may be secondary to systolic heart failure.
3. RLL Pleural Effusion: The patient has a significant RLL pleural effusion that was drained via thoracentesis. The cause of the effusion is unclear, and cultures are pending.
4. Pulmonary Hemorrhage: The patient had an episode of pulmonary hemorrhage, possibly related to anticoagulation therapy.
5. Bacteremia: The patient has bacteremia, likely originating from the lungs due to recent pneumonia.
6. Renal Failure: The patient

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, COPD, admitted to OSH with pneumonia,
   complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF,
   transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.
   .
   # hypoxia - likely multifactorial, with contributions from apparent RLL
   PNA, pulmonary edema 2/2 systolic CHF requiring intermittent diuresis,
   RLL pleural effusion s/p 800cc thoracentesis (culture data not
   available), and an episode of pulmonary hemorhhage felt [**12-31**]
   anticoagulation.  at present, she is oxygenating well, and could be
   weaned down on her PEEP, with consideration of PS trial.  she
   continuous to have considerably bloody secretions. while her CXR is
   without significant pulmonary edema, focal infiltrate, she continues to
   have a RLL effusion.
   - hold off on further diuresis given concern for critical AS.
   - review CT imaging tonight, consider CT CHEST in AM.
   - obtain TTE in AM.
   - continue vancomcyin/zosyn for HCAP.
   - check sputum cx.
   - f/u OSH blood, sputum, and thoracentesis cultures (call in AM, per
   LDH, fluid was transudative, but protein unknown, empyema unlikelygiven
   pH 7.5).
   - wean peep, repeat ABG tonight, consider trial PS.
   - consider repeat bronch in AM if persistantly blood secretions.
   - switch sedation to fentanyl/versed bolus sedation.
   - continue prednisone, start tapering as below.
   .
   # aortic stenosis - report of critical AS on TTE at OSH.  unclear what
   her baseline functional status is, as per her husband, she does not
   have regular angina, or syncope.  she's been "sleeping all the time"
   the past few weeks, so unclear if she has been having symptoms of CHF.
   per discharge summary was transferred here for discussion of valve
   surgery/valvuloplasty.
   - repeat TTE in AM.
   - consider cardiology consult in AM.
   - hold off on further diuresis, nitrates.
   .
   # ARF - no known renal dysfunction.  found to have mild left
   hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by urology with plan to follow
   clinically.  ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic
   stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction.
   - check UA/UCx.
   - check urine lytes.
   - renal ultrasound in AM.
   - follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for
   UOP<30cc/hr.
   .
   # bacteremia - source unclear, but likely pulmonary given recent
   pneumonia.
   - continue vancomycin.
   - TTE in AM, and consider TEE.
   .
   # transaminitis - h/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  abdominal usn and ct abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   - trend LFTs, add-on lipase.
   - repeat abdominal usn in AM.
   .
   # thrombocytopenia - more likely [**12-31**] underlying liver disease, now with
   reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  ddx also includes DIC,
   HUS/TTP given mild ARF, and HITT, though time course is unclear (he
   received heparin sc tid and lovenox at OSH)
   - check smear to r/o schistocytes (ARF, anemia, thrombocytopenia).
   - check DIC labs.
   - hold off sending HITT assay unless drops further.
   .
   # COPD - unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**], but not on home O2.  no clear wheezing
   on exam presently, so feel COPD less likely.
   - taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - obtain OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**] in AM.
   .
   # h/o aortic valvular thrombus - chronically anticoagulated, though
   held in the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrage (though only
   received 1U PRBC for this at OSH).   no thrombus seen on his recent TTE
   at OSH.
   - hold lovenox/coumadin for now, discuss with cardiology in AM based on
   repeat TTE here.
   - cardiology consult in AM.
   .
   # sacral decub - pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - air mattress.
   - wound care consult.
   .
   # h/o hyponatremia - resolved presently, receiving 300cc free water
   boluses.
   - trend na in am.
   .
   # OA - receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  a rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - continue morphine 0.5mg iv q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # anxiety - per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # elevated FSBS - no known history of DM,  but on steroids, with
   elevated FSBS.
   - cover with HISS.
   .
   # h/o SVT - continue cardizem 60mg po q6h.
   .
   # h/o GERD - switch to famotidine given pt intubated.
   .
   # HTN - hold lisinopril given ARF, avoid nitro gtt given AS.
   .
   # hyperlipidemia - continue home regimen of statin.
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now.
   - nutrition consult in AM re tube feeds.
   - consider replacing NGT with OGT if not getting extubated soon.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots, h2 blocker.
   .
   # Access: PIV, L IJ TLC, A-LINE.
   .
   # Code: FULL CODE
   .

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and pneumonia who is currently admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). The patient requires intubation and mechanical ventilation due to hypoxic respiratory failure and is also experiencing acute kidney injury (ARF), bacteremia, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, and a sacral decubitus ulcer.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Critical aortic stenosis (AS): The patient has a reported critical AS on TTE at OSH. This condition may lead to syncope, angina, or even sudden cardiac arrest if not managed properly.

2. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient has mild left hydronephrosis at OSH and is being evaluated for pre-renal azotemia, aortic stenosis, antibiotic-induced nephrotoxicity, or obstruction. If left untreated, ARF can progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.

3. Bacteremia: The patient's source of bacteremia is unclear, but it is likely pulmonary given the recent pneumonia. Failure to treat bacteremia may lead to sepsis and septic shock.

4. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may be related to autoimmune hepatitis or cirrhosis. Close monitoring of liver

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU and has been diagnosed with respiratory failure and impaired skin integrity. The patient is on invasive ventilation, arterial line, and multi-lumen catheter.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Since the patient is on invasive ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP, which is a type of lung infection caused by bacteria.

2. Pressure ulcers: Impaired skin integrity increases the risk of developing pressure ulcers, also known as bedsores. These ulcers can occur due to prolonged periods of immobility and increased pressure on certain areas of the body.

3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The use of multi-lumen catheters and immobilization in the ICU increases the risk of developing DVT, which is a blood clot that forms in a deep vein.

4. Nosocomial infections: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU and invasive procedures increase the risk of nosocomial infections, such as catheter-related bloodstream infections or surgical site infections.

5. Delirium: Critically ill patients in the ICU are at risk of developing delirium, which is a sudden change in mental status characterized by confusion, disorientation, and agitation.

6. Medication errors: With multiple medications and infusions being administered, there is a risk of medication errors, such as incorrect dosages or administration of the wrong medication.

7.

- Urological evaluation revealing urotehial thickening of renal pelvices suggestive

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and pneumonia. She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for difficulty weaning off the ventilator and consideration of valvuloplasty.

The patient's current condition includes:
- Respiratory failure: Multifactorial, with contributions from pneumonia, pulmonary edema due to systolic congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hemorrhage.
- Critical aortic stenosis: Unclear baseline functional status, no regular angina or syncope.
- Acute renal failure (ARF): No known renal dysfunction, mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and planned urology consultation.
- Bacteremia: Source unclear, likely pulmonary given recent pneumonia.
- Transaminitis: History of autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear. Normal LFTs on admission to OSH and on discharge. Abdominal ultrasound (US) and CT abdomen/pelvis at OSH without evidence of right upper quadrant (RUQ) process.
- Thrombocytopenia: More likely underlying liver disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia. Differential diagnosis includes disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)/thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
- COPD: Unclear baseline, but not on home oxygen. No clear wheezing on exam presently.
- History of aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated, though held in the setting of significant pulmonary hemorrhage. No thrombus seen on recent TTE at OSH.
- Sacral decubitus ulcer: Stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not probe to bone.
- Hyponatremia: Resolved presently.
- Osteoarthritis: Receiving morphine for pain management.
- Anxiety: Receiving lorazepam for agitation.
- Elevated fasting blood sugar (FSBS): No known history of diabetes, but on steroids with elevated FSBS.

The patient is currently receiving various medications, including vandocycline, piperacillin/tazobactam, propofol, lorazepam, pantoprazole, and morphine. She is also receiving tube feeds through a nasogastric (NG) tube.

- Sacral decubitus ulcer: Stage 2 ulcer, does not probe to bone.
- Hyponatremia: Resolved presently.

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, severe COPD, and admitted to the ICU for pneumonia complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation. She has been diagnosed with mitral valve endocarditis, critical aortic stenosis, anemia, acute renal failure, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, and a sacral decubitus ulcer.

The patient's respiratory failure is likely multifactorial with contributions from severe COPD, pneumonia, pulmonary edema secondary to systolic heart failure, and pulmonary hemorrhage. She has been treated with full courses of antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia and mitral valve endocarditis. The patient's blood cultures have grown pansensitive Streptococcus salivarius, and she is being started on a 6-week course of penicillin for this.

The patient's anemia may be due to bloody secretions from the endotracheal tube and guaiac-positive stools. Renal function is impaired, and the patient is on hemodialysis. The transaminitis could be related to autoimmune hepatitis, congestive hepatopathy, or an autoimmune process. Thrombocytopenia is likely due to underlying liver disease and reactive to bacteremia and pneumonia.

The patient has a history of aortic valvular thrombus but no thrombus is seen on TTE. She has a new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o aortic stenosis, COPD, admitted to OSH with pneumonia,
   complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, ARF,
   transferred for difficulty weaning and question of valvuloplasty.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   PNA, pulmonary edema 2/2 systolic CHF requiring intermittent diuresis
   and s/p drainage 800cc reportedly transudative fluid via R
   thoracentesis at OSH, and pulmonary hemorrhage felt [**12-31**] anticoagulation
   and ?trauma. Bronch yesterday showed lingular abrasion as likely
   source; continuing to suction bloody secretions. Sputum cx growing only
   yeast to date.
   - Patient appears to have been treated with full course of vanc/CTX.
   D/c zosyn and vanc.
   - F/u OSH cx (blood, sputum, thoracentesis)
   - Cycle Hct to ensure stable
   - Holding coumadin (also no longer e/o AV thrombus)
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Wean PEEP, trial of pressure support as tolerated. Of note, intubated
   x 13 days, and may need to have trach.
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD
   - F/u final read of CT chest
   # Hypertension: Likely underlying essential hypertension exacerbated by
   anxiety as resolved when fell asleep.
   - gentle diuresis for fluid goal of even- to slightly positive
   .
   # Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of hospital stay at
   [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius. TTE shows posterior
   MV leaflet endocarditis.
   - Start PCN for Strep viridans
   - ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   .
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - Will notify Cards on Monday of evaluation for possible valvuloplasty
   - Not candidate for AV replacement given clinical status
   - Gentle lasix for goal even
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   .
   # ARF: No known renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up. Found
   to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with plan
   to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis but
   did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as well
   as chronic renal dysfunction. Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Given + yeast in UA and radiologic finding suggestive of possible
   fungal UTI, consider ID consult for appropriate drug in this patient
   with mild transaminitis
   .
   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  Abdominal U/S and CT abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Abd u/s here suggests chronic liver disease. Pt currently w/o RUQ pain.
   Ddx includes congestive hepatopathy and autoimmune process.
   - F/u LFTs today and trend
   - Gentle diuresis as above
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  Ddx
   also includes HITT. No schistocytes on smear to suggest [**Doctor First Name 2674**], and DIC
   unlikely with INR normalizing off coumadin and fibrinogen >100.
   - F/u HIT Ab
   .
   # COPD: Severe emphysema on CT chest with unclear baseline [**Name (NI) 4232**] but not
   on home O2.  No clear wheezing on exam presently, so feel acute
   exacerbation of COPD less likely.
   - Taper prednisone 60mg po qdaily to 50mg x3d.
   - Continue albuterol, atrovent inhalers.
   - Consider obtaining OSH [**Name (NI) 4232**]
   .
   # H/o aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated but held in
   the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrhage (though only received
   1U PRBC for this at OSH). No thrombus seen on his recent TTE at OSH or
   here.
   - Systemic anticoagulation discontinued; can consider d/w Cards
   .
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   .
   # H/o hyponatremia: Resolved presently
   - Trend Na daily.
   .
   # OA: Receiving morphine 2mg po prn pain.  Per husband, she takes
   percocet at home for pain, but he is unsure where.  A rheumatology note
   indicates she takes percocet for chronic intermittent chest wall pain.
   - Continue morphine 0.5mg IV q6hr prn pain.
   .
   # Anxiety: Per husband, takes anti-anxiety medications at home, and
   receiving lorazepam 0.5-2mg q1hr prn agitation at OSH.
   - Continue prn ativan, and monitor for s/sx of withdrawl.
   .
   # Elevated FSBS: No known history of DM, with elevated FSBS on steroids
   - Cover with HISS
   .
   # H/o SVT: Monitor on tele
   .
   # HTN: Holding lisinopril given ARF; avoid nitro or neg inotropes given
   AS
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Holding home statin given transaminitis.

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and pneumonia who is currently admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure. She has been treated with antibiotics and intubated. The patient has several medical complications including endocarditis, acute renal failure (ARF), transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, sacral decubitus ulcer, hyponatremia, osteoarthritis, anxiety, elevated fasting blood sugar (FSBS), and a history of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). She also has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient's current medications include penicillin G, furosemide, fentanyl, midazolam, pantoprazole, and lorazepam.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is already experiencing respiratory failure, which requires mechanical ventilation and careful monitoring.
2. Endocarditis: Blood cultures positive for pansensitive Streptococcus salivarius, indicating possible endocarditis. The patient requires treatment with penicillin for this condition.
3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient has an elevated creatinine level and is showing signs of renal dysfunction. Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the cause and appropriate treatment.
4. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, which may indicate liver dysfunction or

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient has several medical conditions and potential complications:

1. Arterial line complications: The patient had an arterial line placed and subsequently developed a blood infection (bacteremia) with Streptococcus salivarius, which is sensitive to penicillin. This indicates a potential risk for endocarditis or sepsis.

2. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation profile shows prolonged PTT and low fibrinogen levels. This may indicate a bleeding tendency or the presence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

3. Decubitus ulcer: The patient has a pre-existing decubitus ulcer that was present at admission. This indicates potential pressure injury or bed sore, which requires regular turning and pressure relief.

4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is consistently elevated in the 210s/120s range. This could be due to stress, pain, medication side effects, or underlying chronic hypertension.

5. Hypokalemia: The patient's potassium levels are low, indicating hypokalemia. This can cause muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias, and other electrolyte imbalances.

6. Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a high tidal volume (380 mL) and moderate PEEP (10 cmH2O). The ABG results show a slightly elevated PaCO2 and low pH, suggesting hypoventilation or inadequate ventilation.

Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for the patient:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated due to hypoxic respiratory failure. There is a concern for pneumonia, pulmonary edema secondary to systolic heart failure, and pulmonary hemorrhage. The presence of bloody secretions and yeast in sputum cultures suggests an ongoing respiratory infection.

2. Endocarditis: Blood cultures positive for Strep viridans, which is sensitive to penicillin. The patient has a positive TTE showing posterior MV leaflet endocarditis. This indicates a possible infection of the heart valves.

3. Aortic stenosis (AS): The patient has critical AS on TTE. There is uncertainty regarding her baseline functional status, and she does not have regular angina or syncope. There is a plan to notify cards on Monday for evaluation for possible valvuloplasty.

4. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine level is elevated and trending up. There is evidence of left hydronephrosis at OSH, suggesting potential obstruction. The differential diagnosis includes pre-renal azotemia, aortic stenosis, antibiotics-induced nephrotoxicity, and obstruction.

5. Transaminitis: The patient has a history of autoimmune hepatitis, but the baseline is unclear. Liver function tests were normal upon admission to OSH and on discharge. There is evidence of chronic liver disease

The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of aortic stenosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pneumonia, acute respiratory failure (ARF), and endocarditis. She has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation and potential valvuloplasty.

The patient's current condition includes:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has likely multifactorial respiratory failure with contributions from pneumonia, pulmonary edema due to systolic congestive heart failure (CHF), and pulmonary hemorrhage. She is still experiencing bloody secretions, and sputum cultures are growing only yeast.
2. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is likely underlying essential hypertension exacerbated by anxiety, which resolved when she fell asleep.
3. Endocarditis: Blood cultures are positive for pansensitive Streptococcus salivarius, and a transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) shows posterior mitral valve leaflet endocarditis. The patient will start penicillin for Strep viridans and receive an infectious disease consultation for treatment and outpatient follow-up.
4. Aortic stenosis (AS): The patient has critical AS on TTE, and it is unclear about her baseline functional status. She does not have regular angina or syncope. The patient will be evaluated for possible valvuloplasty and will not be a candidate for aortic valve replacement given her clinical

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient briefly tried
   on PEEP of 6 yesterday but appeared uncomfortable, bradycardia, with
   ABG 7.45/48/63.  Continues to have bloody secretions.  Sputum cultures
   only with yeast to date.
   - Increase sedation for comfort
   - Patient has received full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - To receive trach, hopefully today with IP
   - Plan on DDAVP prior to trach
   - F/u cx
   - Cycle Hct to ensure stable
   - Holding coumadin
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.  EKG
s have been unchanged
   to date.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**])
   - f/u ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - appreciate cardiology consult today regarding possible interventions,
   she appears to not be a candidate for AV replacement given clinical
   status and endocarditis
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Has bloody secretions from ET tube, oozing from picc site,
   guaiac positive stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis,
   likely due to mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low,
   likely due to critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts [**Hospital1 **]
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   .
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up.
   Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with
   plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis
   but did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as
   well as chronic renal dysfunction. Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Cx with yeast -> foley changed.
   - f/u urine cx
   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  Abdominal U/S and CT abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Abd u/s here suggests chronic liver disease. Pt currently w/o RUQ pain.
   Ddx includes congestive hepatopathy and autoimmune process.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Holding statin
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  Ddx
   also includes HITT. No schistocytes on smear to suggest [**Doctor First Name 2674**], and DIC
   unlikely with INR normalizing off coumadin and fibrinogen >100.
   - F/u HIT Ab
   - Consider hemolysis from endocarditis
   # H/o aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated but held in
   the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrhage (though only received
   1U PRBC for this at OSH). No thrombus seen on TTE at OSH or here.
   - Systemic anticoagulation discontinued; can consider d/w Cards utility
   of continuing anti-coagulation when stable
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   .
   # HTN: Worsens in setting of anxiety. Holding lisinopril given ARF;
   avoid nitro or neg inotropes given AS. Labetolol was effective for her
   HTN. Would use this again if necessary.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TF (on hold for procedure)

The patient's conditions include respiratory failure, mitral valve endocarditis, critical aortic stenosis, anemia, acute renal failure, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, and a history of aortic valvular thrombus.

2. Mitral Valve Endocarditis: The patient has positive blood cultures growing pansensitive S. salivarius, indicating an infection of the mitral valve. This requires long-term antibiotic therapy and may require surgical intervention.

   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient briefly tried
   on PEEP of 6 yesterday but appeared uncomfortable with ABG 7.45/48/63.
   Continues to have bloody secretions.  Sputum cultures only with yeast
   to date.
   - Patient has received full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - To receive trach today with IP
   - F/u cx
   - Cycle Hct to ensure stable
   - Holding coumadin
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.  EKG
s have been unchanged
   to date.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**])
   - ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - appreciate cardiology consult today regarding possible interventions,
   she appears to not be s candidate for AV replacement given clinical
   status and endocarditis
   - Gentle lasix with gtt for goal even
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Has bloody secretions from ET tube, oozing from picc site,
   guaiac positive stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis,
   likely due to mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low,
   likely due to critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts [**Hospital1 **]
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   .
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up.
   Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with
   plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis
   but did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as
   well as chronic renal dysfunction. Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - f/u urine cx
   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  Abdominal U/S and CT abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Abd u/s here suggests chronic liver disease. Pt currently w/o RUQ pain.
   Ddx includes congestive hepatopathy and autoimmune process.
   - F/u LFTs today and trend
   - Gentle diuresis as above
   - Holding statin
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  Ddx
   also includes HITT. No schistocytes on smear to suggest [**Doctor First Name 2674**], and DIC
   unlikely with INR normalizing off coumadin and fibrinogen >100.
   - F/u HIT Ab
   - Consider hemolysis from endocarditis->will check labs today
   # H/o aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated but held in
   the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrhage (though only received
   1U PRBC for this at OSH). No thrombus seen on TTE at OSH or here.
   - Systemic anticoagulation discontinued; can consider d/w Cards utility
   of continuing anti-coagulation when stable
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   .
   # HTN: Worsens in setting of anxiety. Holding lisinopril given ARF;
   avoid nitro or neg inotropes given AS. Labetolol was effective for her
   last pm. Would use this again if necessary.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to the hospital with pneumonia and hypoxic respiratory failure. She required intubation and was transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty for critical AS. She was found to have mitral valve endocarditis. The patient's current conditions include respiratory failure, mitral valve endocarditis, critical aortic stenosis, anemia, acute renal failure, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, and a history of aortic valvular thrombus. She also has a new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer and hypertension.

Potential medical complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is still experiencing respiratory failure, likely due to severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema. She has been receiving full courses of vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam for hospital-acquired pneumonia. A tracheostomy is planned today with percutaneous dilatational tracheostomy (IP). Daily follow-up chest X-rays are needed.
2. Mitral valve endocarditis: The patient has positive blood cultures growing pansensitive Strep salivarius. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) showed posterior MV leaflet endocarditis. A cardiology consult is required regarding possible interventions, considering her clinical status and endocarditis

The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to the hospital with pneumonia and subsequent hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation. She has been diagnosed with mitral valve endocarditis, critical aortic stenosis, anemia, acute renal failure, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, and a history of aortic valvular thrombus. She also has a sacral decubitus ulcer and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, and there is a concern for ongoing difficulty weaning her off the ventilator due to severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema. The presence of bloody secretions and yeast in sputum cultures may indicate an ongoing infection.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has been increasing, suggesting a possible infection. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of infection.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, which could be due to inadequate free water intake. This may be related to her prolonged intubation.
4. Mitral Valve Endocarditis: The patient has positive blood cultures growing pansensitive S. salivarius, and a TTE showing posterior MV leaflet endocarditis. She requires an extended course of penicillin for Strep salivarius per

   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient briefly tried
   on PEEP of 6 yesterday but appeared uncomfortable, bradycardia, with
   ABG 7.45/48/63.  Continues to have bloody secretions.  Sputum cultures
   only with yeast to date.
   - Increase sedation for comfort
   - Patient has received full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - To receive trach, hopefully today with IP
   - Plan on DDAVP prior to trach
   - F/u cx
   - Cycle Hct to ensure stable
   - Holding coumadin
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation
   #Leukocytosis- Has been creeping up for last 24 hours, with significant
   increase today.  No obvious source.
   - CXR today
   - send blood and urine cx
   - f/u imaging to evaluate for dental abscess
   - check c. diff
   - pull central line
   - consider abdominal CT per ID recs
   #Hypernatremia- Difficult to assess fluid status in this patient,
   however given her prolonged intubation she may be taking in inadequate
   free water.
   - increase free water flushes for TF
   - recheck Na this pm
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.  EKG
s have been unchanged
   to date.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**])
   - f/u ID consult for treatment course and outpt f/u of endocarditis
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - appreciate cardiology consult today regarding possible interventions,
   she appears to not be a candidate for AV replacement given clinical
   status and endocarditis
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Has bloody secretions from ET tube, oozing from picc site,
   guaiac positive stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis,
   likely due to mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low,
   likely due to critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts [**Hospital1 **]
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   .
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up.
   Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with
   plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis
   but did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as
   well as chronic renal dysfunction. Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Cx with yeast -> foley changed.
   - f/u urine cx
   # Transaminitis: H/o autoimmune hepatitis, baseline unclear.  LFTs
   normal on admission to OSH, and on discharge ALT 49, AST AST 51,
   amylase 238.  Abdominal U/S and CT abd/pelvis at OSH without evidence
   of RUQ process, though elevated INR and low albumin suggest cirrhosis.
   Abd u/s here suggests chronic liver disease. Pt currently w/o RUQ pain.
   Ddx includes congestive hepatopathy and autoimmune process.
   - Trend LFTs
   - Holding statin
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia.  Ddx
   also includes HITT. No schistocytes on smear to suggest [**Doctor First Name 2674**], and DIC
   unlikely with INR normalizing off coumadin and fibrinogen >100.
   - F/u HIT Ab
   - Consider hemolysis from endocarditis
   # H/o aortic valvular thrombus: Chronically anticoagulated but held in
   the setting of significant pulmonary hemhorrhage (though only received
   1U PRBC for this at OSH). No thrombus seen on TTE at OSH or here.
   - Systemic anticoagulation discontinued; can consider d/w Cards utility
   of continuing anti-coagulation when stable
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   .
   # HTN: Worsens in setting of anxiety. Holding lisinopril given ARF;
   avoid nitro or neg inotropes given AS. Labetolol was effective for her
   HTN. Would use this again if necessary.
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, and pneumonia who was admitted to the hospital with hypoxic respiratory failure. She required intubation and was transferred to the ICU for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty for critical AS. The patient was found to have mitral valve endocarditis. She continues to have bloody secretions, and her white blood cell count has been creeping up for the last 24 hours with a significant increase today. She also has hypernatremia and anemia with active red cell lysis likely due to mitral valve vegetations. The patient has renal failure, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, a history of autoimmune hepatitis, and a sacral decubitus ulcer.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has been increasing steadily, indicating an infection or inflammation. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of infection.
3. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and pneumonia. She was admitted to the hospital for respiratory failure requiring intubation, acute renal failure (ARF), and mitral valve endocarditis. The patient has been experiencing bloody secretions, positive yeast in sputum cultures, and positive blood cultures growing pansensitive Strep salivarius. She also has critical aortic stenosis, hypernatremia, anemia, ARF, transaminitis, thrombocytopenia, and a history of autoimmune hepatitis. Additionally, she has a sacral decubitus ulcer and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still experiencing respiratory failure, which is likely multifactorial. It may be caused by severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema.
2. Mitral Valve Endocarditis: The patient has positive blood cultures growing pansensitive Strep salivarius and evidence of mitral valve endocarditis on echocardiogram. She requires a prolonged course of penicillin and close follow-up with an infectious disease specialist.
3. Anemia: The patient has ongoing bloody secretions from the endotracheal tube, oozing from the percutaneous central catheter (PICC) line site, and guaiac-positive stools. Hemolysis

   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient briefly tried
   on PEEP of 6 yesterday but appeared uncomfortable, bradycardia, with
   ABG 7.45/48/63.  Continues to have bloody secretions.  Sputum cultures
   only with yeast to date.
   - Trach and PEG today with IP
   - Patient has received full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - Plan on DDAVP prior to trach
   - F/u cx
   - Cycle Hct to ensure stable
   - Holding coumadin
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation (today is first day
   of 40mg prednisone)
   #Leukocytosis- Has been creeping up for last 24 hours, with significant
   increase today.  No obvious source.
   - CXR today without new infiltrate
   - F/U panorex
   - send blood and urine cx
   - f/u imaging to evaluate for dental abscess
   - check c. diff
   - pull central line after trach/peg
   - consider abdominal CT per ID recs after trach/peg
   #Hypernatremia- Difficult to assess fluid status in this patient,
   however given her prolonged intubation she may be taking in inadequate
   free water.
   - give back 1L free water IV today since TFs held for procedures
   - increase free water flushes for TF
   - recheck Na this pm
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.
   - Concerning today with bradycardia that she has conduction abnormality
   with high junctional escape beats on EKG. F/U cards recs and consider
   temp wire if worsens
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**]) per
   ID recs
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - Hold on diuresis for now. Fluid goal even today.
   - Per cards recs, will consider valvuloplasty if clinical course does
   not improve over next 48 hours
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Has bloody secretions from ET tube, oozing from picc site,
   guaiac positive stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis,
   likely due to mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low,
   likely due to critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts daily as stable for several days
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   .

   now 1.9 . Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by
   Urology with plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did not report
   hydronephrosis but did have urothelial thickening suggesting chronic
   UTI (?fungal) as well as chronic renal dysfunction. Repeat Ucx after
   foley change without fungus.  Ddx currently includes pre-renal [**12-31**]
   diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction. Urine
   lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Stable currently. Hold diuresis as above.
   # Thrombocytopenia: Stably decreased. Likely [**12-31**] underlying liver
   disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and pneumonia but
   HIT antibody positive.
   - f/u serotonin assay and consider other sources including hemolysis
   from the endocarditis as well
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - F/u wound care recs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TF on hold for procedure
   Glycemic Control:  ISS

The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and pneumonia. She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation, acute renal failure (ARF), and mitral valve endocarditis. The patient has been receiving full courses of vancomycin and zosyn for hospital-acquired pneumonia and Strep salivarius endocarditis. She is planned for tracheostomy (trach) and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) today, as well as valvuloplasty if there is no clinical improvement in the next 48 hours. The patient's current medical complications include respiratory failure, leukocytosis, hypernatremia, mitral valve endocarditis, critical aortic stenosis, anemia, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and sacral decubitus ulcer.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still experiencing difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation, and there are ongoing bloody secretions despite receiving full courses of antibiotics. This suggests an ongoing infection or another underlying cause for her respiratory failure.
2. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count has been increasing over the past 24 hours, indicating a potential ongoing infection or inflammatory response.

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   .
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient with
   uneventful placement of trach and PEG yesterday after 1 dose DDAVP.
   Blood gas yesterday evening on 50% FiO2 revealed pO2 56, so FiO2
   increased to 60%, remainder of settings stable with PEEP maintained at
   10.
   - Patient has received full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - F/u cx
   - Hct daily to ensure stable, holding coumadin
   - Gentle diuresis to run pt even
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation (today is day 2 of
   40mg prednisone)
   #Leukocytosis- Down to 23 from 27.  Central line d/c
ed.  CXR revealed
   slight increase in R pleural effusion, no consolidation.  Urine
   legionella negative, remainder of cx with NGTD.  Unable to obtain
   panorex for possible oral source.
   - f/u cx
   - per ID recs, consider imaging of oral cavity for dental abscess, CT
   abd/pelvis for further evaluation of hydronephosis
   - check c. diff
   #Hypernatremia- Improved with increased free water in TF.
   - continue increased free water flushes for TF
   - recheck Na this pm
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.  Bradycardia discussed
   with cards who recommend continuing to monitor, no wire at this time.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**]) per
   ID recs
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope
   - Hold on diuresis for now. Fluid goal even today.
   - Per cards recs, will consider valvuloplasty if clinical course does
   not improve over next 24 hours
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Hct decreased 2 points today s/p trach and PEG placement.
   Continues to have scant bloody secretions from ET tube, guaiac positive
   stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis, likely due to
   mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low, likely due to
   critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts daily as stable for several days
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   .
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up,
   now stable around 2.0 . Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH,
   and seen by Urology with plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did
   not report hydronephrosis but did have urothelial thickening suggesting
   chronic UTI (?fungal) as well as chronic renal dysfunction. Repeat Ucx
   after foley change without fungus.  Ddx currently includes pre-renal
   [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction.
   Urine lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Stable currently. Hold diuresis as above.
   # Thrombocytopenia: Increased plt since heparin held.  Likely [**12-31**]
   underlying liver disease, now with reactive component to bacteremia and
   pneumonia but HIT antibody positive.
   - f/u serotonin assay and consider other sources including hemolysis
   from the endocarditis as well
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - continue wound care
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: TF
   Glycemic Control:

   PICC Line - [**2182-5-13**] 04:32 AM

   VAP:  oral care

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to the hospital with pneumonia and subsequent hypoxic respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient has been diagnosed with mitral valve endocarditis and has undergone tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement.

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   #)Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient with
   uneventful placement of trach and PEG yesterday after 1 dose DDAVP.
   - Transition to PS as more comfortable when able to pull in larger Vt
   spontaneously
   - S/p full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - Resend sputum cx, f/u pending cx
   - Monitor Hct daily, holding coumadin
   - Gentle diuresis with lasix gtt today with goal net neg over 24 h
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation (today is day 2 of
   40mg prednisone)
   #Leukocytosis: Decrease from 27 to 23. Central line d/c
ed.  CXR
   revealed slight increase in R pleural effusion, no consolidation.
   Urine legionella negative, remainder of cx with NGTD.
   - Cont PCN for S. salivarius
   - F/u pending cx, C. diff sent today (BM with suppository)
   - Resend sputum and surveillance bcx
   - Per ID recs, consider imaging of oral cavity for dental abscess but
   unable to obtain panorex for possible oral source. Will hold off
   further imaging for now unless spikes.
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.  Bradycardia discussed
   with cards who recommend continuing to monitor, no wire at this time.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**]) per
   ID recs
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   - Surveillance blood cx; f/u micro data here and OSH
   #Hypernatremia: Improved with increased free water in TF.
   - Continue increased free water flushes for TF
   - Recheck Na this pm
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope.
   - Gentle lasix gtt today as above
   - Per cards recs, will consider valvuloplasty if clinical course does
   not improve over next 24 hours
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Hct decreased 2 points today s/p trach and PEG placement.
   Continues to have scant bloody secretions from ET tube, guaiac positive
   stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis, likely due to
   mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low, likely due to
   critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts daily as stable for several days
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   - Change IV PPI [**Hospital1 **] to po lansoprazole daily
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up,
   now stable around 2.0 . Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH,
   and seen by Urology with plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did
   not report hydronephrosis but did have urothelial thickening suggesting
   chronic UTI (?fungal) as well as chronic renal dysfunction. Repeat Ucx
   after foley change without fungus.  Ddx currently includes pre-renal
   [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction.
   Urine lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Stable currently. Hold diuresis as above.
   # Thrombocytopenia: Increased plt since heparin held; HIT Ab positive.
   Likely  also [**12-31**] underlying liver disease and reactive component from
   infection.
   - F/u serotonin assay and consider other sources including hemolysis
   from the endocarditis as well
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - Continue wound care

- The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, and admitted for pneumonia.
- She required intubation and mechanical ventilation due to hypoxic respiratory failure and was transferred to the ICU for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty.
- The patient was found to have mitral valve endocarditis and is currently on a prolonged course of penicillin for Strep salivarius.
- She has leukocytosis that decreased from 27 to 23 after central line removal.
- The patient's sodium levels improved with increased free water intake.
- She has anemia with a decreasing hemoglobin level due to tracheostomy and peg tube placement, as well as ongoing bloody secretions.
- The patient has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 2.0, and urine cultures are negative for Legionella but positive for S. salivarius.
- She also has thrombocytopenia with increased platelet count after holding heparin and a positive HIT Ab.
- The patient developed a stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's severe COPD and the presence of atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema may contribute to respiratory failure. - Her current condition includes respiratory failure, leukocytosis, mitral valve endocarditis, hypernatremia, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and sacral decubitus ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, with contributions from severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema. She briefly tolerated pressure support ventilation (PS) but changed back to assist-control (AC) due to fatigue. Her Hct has decreased today with continued bloody secretions from the endotracheal tube.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis is decreasing, but she still has yeast growing in her sputum culture. She is being treated for Strep salivarius.

3. Mitral Valve Endocarditis: The patient has positive blood cultures growing pansensitive S. salivarius. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis. Bradycardia is reserved.

   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation (today is day 2 of
   40mg prednisone)
   #Leukocytosis: Decrease from 27 to 23. Central line d/c
ed.  CXR
   revealed slight increase in R pleural effusion, no consolidation.
   Urine legionella negative, remainder of cx with NGTD.
   - Cont PCN for S. salivarius
   - F/u pending cx, C. diff sent today (BM with suppository)
   - Resend sputum and surveillance bcx
   - Per ID recs, consider imaging of oral cavity for dental abscess but
   unable to obtain panorex for possible oral source. Will hold off
   further imaging for now unless spikes.
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.  Bradycardia discussed
   with cards who recommend continuing to monitor, no wire at this time.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**]) per
   ID recs
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   - Surveillance blood cx; f/u micro data here and OSH
   #Hypernatremia: Improved with increased free water in TF.
   - Continue increased free water flushes for TF
   - Recheck Na this pm
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope.
   - Gentle lasix gtt today as above
   - Per cards recs, will consider valvuloplasty if clinical course does
   not improve over next 24 hours
   - Avoid decreasing preload or negative inotropy
   # Anemia:  Hct decreased 2 points today s/p trach and PEG placement.
   Continues to have scant bloody secretions from ET tube, guaiac positive
   stools.  Hemolysis labs suggest active red cell lysis, likely due to
   mitral valve veg.  Retic count inappropriately low, likely due to
   critical illness.
   - Cycle hcts daily as stable for several days
   - Transfuse for hct<21
   - Change IV PPI [**Hospital1 **] to po lansoprazole daily
   .
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up,
   now stable around 2.0 . Found to have mild left hydronephrosis at OSH,
   and seen by Urology with plan to follow clinically. Abd U/S here did
   not report hydronephrosis but did have urothelial thickening suggesting
   chronic UTI (?fungal) as well as chronic renal dysfunction. Repeat Ucx
   after foley change without fungus.  Ddx currently includes pre-renal
   [**12-31**] diuresis vs aortic stenosis, AIN [**12-31**] antibiotics, vs obstruction.
   Urine lytes suggest pre-renal etiology.
   - Follow UOP closely, if CVP < [**7-8**], gentle IVF boluses for UOP<30cc/hr
   - Stable currently. Hold diuresis as above.
   # Thrombocytopenia: Increased plt since heparin held; HIT Ab positive.
   Likely  also [**12-31**] underlying liver disease and reactive component from
   infection.
   - F/u serotonin assay and consider other sources including hemolysis
   from the endocarditis as well
   # Sacral decub: Pt with new stage 2 sacral decubitus ulcer, does not
   probe to bone.
   - Air mattress.
   - Continue wound care

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, and pneumonia. She was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure and underwent tracheostomy and PEG placement. The patient has been diagnosed with mitral valve endocarditis and has positive blood cultures growing pansensitive S. salivarius. She also has critical AS, anemia, acute renal failure, thrombocytopenia, and a sacral decubitus ulcer.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still dependent on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxic respiratory failure. The ventilator settings need to be closely monitored, and weaning attempts should be made cautiously.
2. Mitral Valve Endocarditis: The patient's blood cultures are positive for S. salivarius, indicating an ongoing infection. She requires a prolonged course of antibiotics, and the possibility of valve replacement should be considered.
3. Critical Aortic Stenosis (AS): The patient has critical AS, which can lead to syncope, heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. Valvuloplasty or valve replacement may be necessary if her clinical course does not improve.
4. Anemia: The patient's Hct levels are decreasing, suggesting ongoing blood loss or hemolysis. Blood transfusion may be required, and further investigation into the cause of hemolysis is needed.
5. Acute Renal Failure (ARF):

The respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, including severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema. The patient's hematocrit levels have slightly decreased today with ongoing bloody secretions from the endotracheal tube. She is currently +500 cc for fluid balance.

The patient has completed a full course of vancomycin and zosyn for hospital-acquired pneumonia. She continues on a lasix drip for fluid management goals. A trial of pressure support ventilation will be attempted today. Blood cultures were positive on day 2 of the hospital stay, growing pansensitive Strep salivarius, and a TTE showed posterior MV leaflet endocarditis. The patient has been started on a 6-week course of penicillin for Strep salivarius per ID recommendations. Daily ECGs will be monitored for the development of heart block.

The potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided are:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has hypoxemic respiratory failure requiring intubation. There are multiple factors contributing to this, including severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema. The patient briefly tolerated pressure support ventilation (PS) but changed back to assist-control (AC) mode due to fatigue.

2. Leukocytosis: The patient initially had leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 27.1 K/uL. It continues to decrease. Microbiology results show yeast growing in sputum, but C. difficile is negative. Penicillin was continued for Strep salivarius.

3. Mitral valve endocarditis: Blood cultures were positive for pansensitive Strep salivarius, and trans-thoracic echocardiography (TTE) shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis. Bradycardia has been reserved, and the patient will continue on a 6-week course of penicillin for Strep salivarius per Infectious Disease recommendations. Daily ECGs

   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage and edema.  Patient briefly
   tolerated PS, then changed back to AC for fatigue.  Hct slowly
   decreasing today with continued bloody secretions from ET tube.  She is
   currently about even for LOS fluid balance.  Lasix drip on at 1
   overnight and off this am.
   - S/p full course of vanc/zosyn for HAP
   - i/o goal: even
   - PS trial today as tolerated
 attempt [**4-7**] pressure support
   - f/u pending cx
   - Check pm hct, transfuse for hct <21(see below)
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation (today is day 3 of
   40mg prednisone)
   - transition fentanyl gtt to patch of 25 mcg/24hr, transition midaz to
   NG valium.
   # Anemia: Hct continues to slowly trend down (27 -> 24 ->22).  Sources
   include continued bloody secretions, guiaic positive stools, hemolysis
   from valve vegetation.
   - transfuse 2 u pRBC
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now growing out pansensitive S. salivarius.
   TTE shows posterior MV leaflet endocarditis.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**]) per

   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block

   - Cards would consider valvuloplasty after completion of abx course
   # Hypertension: Appears to be related to agitation (sedation decreased
   yesterday, BP increases when patient stimulated)

   - would not start home CCB at this time given AS
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH and trending up,
   now slowly increasing (2.0 -> 2.4) . Found to have mild left
   hydronephrosis at OSH, and seen by Urology with plan to follow
   clinically. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis but did have
   urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as well as
   chronic renal dysfunction. Repeat Ucx after foley change with fungus.
   Urine negative for eos.

   #Leukocytosis: Continues to decrease. Micro with yeast growing in urine
   and sputum, c. diff negative.

   Likely  also [**12-31**] underlying liver disease and reactive component from
   infection.
   - F/u serotonin assay

Summary:
The patient is a 75-year-old woman with a history of severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, and pneumonia. She was admitted to the hospital with respiratory failure and atrial fibrillation. The patient underwent intubation and was transferred to the ICU for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty for critical aortic stenosis. During her stay, she was found to have mitral valve endocarditis. She has been treated with a full course of vancomycin and zosyn for hospital-acquired pneumonia. The patient's respiratory failure is likely multifactorial, with contributions from severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema. Her hemoglobin concentration continues to decrease, and she has bloody secretions from the endotracheal tube. She is currently even for fluid balance. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to severe COPD, atelectasis, hemorrhage, and edema. It is crucial to closely monitor her respiratory status and provide appropriate supportive care.
2. Anemia: The patient's hemoglobin concentration is decreasing, and she has bloody secretions from the endotracheal tube. This suggests ongoing blood loss, which needs to be investigated and managed promptly.
3. Mitral Valve Endocarditis: The patient has been diagnosed with mitral valve endocarditis. She has positive blood cultures growing pansensitive Strep salivarius

The patient was found to have mitral valve endocarditis.

The patient's vital signs show a heart rate within normal limits, blood pressure slightly elevated, respiratory rate within normal limits, and oxygen saturation at 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 380 mL and a peak inspiratory pressure of 23 cmH2O. The physical examination reveals that the patient is intubated and sedated, with dry mucous membranes and bronchial breath sounds. Her abdomen is soft with normal bowel sounds, and extremities are warm and well-perfused. The patient is neurologically intact, following commands.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and platelet count within normal limits. Blood glucose levels vary throughout the day but remain within normal limits. Electrolyte levels are within normal range except for slightly low potassium and magnesium levels. Liver function tests are mildly abnormal, and renal function tests are within normal

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient has a history of valvuloplasty being considered after completing antibiotic therapy, and the recommendation for a CT abdomen/pelvis could not be given due to acute renal failure (ARF). The patient is currently tolerating passive range of motion (PS) for 8 hours and is back on rate for overnight. The patient's blood pressure runs higher when awake and agitated during the weaning of sedation. The patient's allergies include heparin agents and thrombocytopenia.

The patient's last dose of antibiotics was Penicillin G potassium on [**2182-5-17**] at 05:54 AM. The patient is receiving various infusions, including other ICU medications and other medications.

The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below. The flowsheet data shows vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, respiratory support, and laboratory values.

The patient's lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, decreased hematocrit, and normal platelet count. Renal function tests show an increased creatinine level. Blood glucose levels have been fluctuating. Electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for slightly low potassium and magnesium levels. Liver function tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase and aspartate aminotransferase levels. Cardiac enzymes are within normal range. Other

   Assessment and Plan
   75F with h/o severe aortic stenosis, severe COPD, admitted to OSH with
   pneumonia, complicated by hypoxic respiratory failure requiring
   intubation, ARF, transferred for difficulty weaning and valvuloplasty
   for critical AS and found to have mitral valve endocarditis.
   # Respiratory failure: Likely multifactorial with contributions from
   severe COPD, atalectasis, hemorrhage, edema and  HAP s/p full course of
   vanc/zosyn
   - i/o goal: even off lasix gtt
   - decrease free water flushes to minimize intake.
   - Cte PS at 8/8 today and wean as tolerated
   - f/u pending cx
   - Continue prednisone taper for COPD exacerbation (today is day 1 of
   30mg prednisone)
   - transition fentanyl gtt to patch of 25 mcg/24hr, transition midaz to
   NG valium.
   # Embolic CVA:
   - Appreciate Neuro recs
   - F/U MRI FR
   - Not on heparin currently given persistent oozing post-trach and new
   CVA. D/W neuro best time to re-start hep gtt/coumadin.
   - LDL elevated but has transaminitis at baseline so statin not a good
   option for her. As CVA was embolic do not feel she would benefit from
   this therapy as CVA prevention but with DM may consider adding
   different class of cholesterol lowering medication in the future.
   - Will need family discussion for goals of care.
   # Anemia: Hct had slowly trended down over course of last couple of
   days.  Sources include continued bloody secretions, guiaic positive
   stools, hemolysis from valve vegetation.  Received one unit pRBCs with
   inappropriate bump but after second unit up to 31 (from 24) so
   appropriate. Likely first lab results inaccurate.
   - Trend hcts daily
   # Mitral Valve Endocarditis
 Blood cultures positive on day 2 of
   hospital stay at [**Hospital1 **], now with pansensitive S. salivarius. TTE shows
   posterior MV leaflet endocarditis. Now with embolic CVA. Patient does
   not want CT surgery so will not reconsult.
   - Continue PCN for Strep salivarius (6 week course started on [**4-30**]) per
   ID recs
   - Daily ECGs to monitor for development of heart block
   - f/u blood cx
   - f/u CT head/face FR for ?dental abscess
   # AS: Critical AS on TTE. Unclear what her baseline functional status
   is, she does not have regular angina, or syncope.
   - Fluid goal even
   - Cards would consider valvuloplasty after completion of abx course but
   this may change given new CVA
   # Hypertension: Appears to be related to agitation (sedation decreased
   yesterday, BP increases when patient stimulated)
   - Permissive hypertension (goal 150-160) for CVA
   - D/c art line today.
   # ARF: No known h/o renal dysfunction. Cr 1.2 at OSH now stable at
   around 2 daily. Abd U/S here did not report hydronephrosis but did have
   urothelial thickening suggesting chronic UTI (?fungal) as well as
   chronic renal dysfunction. Repeat Ucx after foley change with fungus.
   Urine negative for eos.
   - MR abd not indicated per radiology
   - cannot give contrast based on renal function.
   # Elevated LFTs: Bili and alk phos elevated today. ? increase hemolysis
   due to valve vs. biliary pathology.
   - repeat LFTs and RUQ U/S if continued elevation.
   # Thrombocytopenia: Increased plt since heparin held; HIT Ab positive.
   Likely  also [**12-31**] underlying liver disease and reactive component from
   infection.
   - F/u serotonin assay
